awd_titl_txt: Renewal: Cybercorps: Scholarship for Service at FS
awd_abstract_narration:
The Florida State University (FSU) proposes to add four new cohorts of undergraduate and graduate students to their existing CyberCorps(R) Scholarship for Service (SFS) program in cybersecurity with strong integration of education and research. The project will have an immediate impact on the information assurance and forensics capabilities of the federal workforce by providing graduates with general computing and security skills. The program components are designed to have a broad and lasting impact. Existing efforts to engage members of underrepresented groups and non-traditional students will be intensified. CyberCorps(R) students will collaborate on real-world projects to gain practical experience and enhance internship and job placement prospects. The proposed project addresses the current personnel gap in cybersecurity for the national information infrastructure. Through a formal relationship with Florida A&M University, the project is making a focused effort to recruit students from underrepresented groups into the program and has academic support programs to foster their success. The cybersecurity program is the most popular graduate program in FSU's computer science department and the prospect of a potential employment within the Federal Government has a significant impact on the number of applying students, including minority and female students.

The program is graduating skilled information assurance and forensics professionals with strong leadership skills and a commitment to public service. The program integrates rigorous, hands-on learning with research, professional development and outreach activities. The students will serve as summer interns to gain practical experience and will join federal agencies or other eligible entities upon graduation. The program has a well-established infrastructure for retention and mentoring. It includes a flexible selection procedure, offering admission by exception and choices of alternative degree programs, for strong cybersecurity candidates who otherwise do not meet the minimum computer science degree requirements. It is intended to broaden the scope of the cybersecurity program and attract minority and female applicants. FSU has received the DHS/NSA designation as the National Center of Academic Excellence in Information Assurance and Cyber Defense. The project includes an assessment and evaluation plan coordinated by an independent evaluator to ensure that the project achieves its objectives. The project's results are being disseminated through conference and professional presentations.

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report

  1. The Department of Computer Science (CS) at Florida State University (FSU), Tallahassee, has developed a robust infrastructure for cybersecurity education that targets analytical, computational and problem solving skills, to enable CyberCorps (SFS) scholars to play a leading role in analyzing and better understanding the cybersecurity threat model and to develop protection policies/mechanisms. This includes the establishment of practical-oriented (Hands-on and Challenge-Response) cybersecurity component of the MS degree in Computer Science (Cybersecurity Major). This educational program has contributed to the designation of FSU as a National Center of Academic Excellence in Cyber Defense (CAE-CD) and a National Center of Academic Excellence in Research (CAE-R).
  2. Through the CyberCorps program, we recruited some of the most qualified and strongly motivated students from the College of Arts and Sciences (including the CS and Mathematics Departments), the College of Criminology & Criminal Justice, the FAMU-FSU College of  Engineering, as well as other schools in Florida. Our educational program offers scholars a range of courses in cyber security and cyber defense both at the undergraduate and graduate levels, while providing an environment that encourages learning and research in cybersecurity.
  3. We succesfully recruited six cohorts with an average of eight students per year for 2017-2022, with another three recruited in Spring 2023 (who will continue being funded by the Renewal Award). In total 51 scholars were supported by this award. The program attracted a significant number of female students and underrepresented minorities. All our scholars graduated within three years of receiving the scholarship. We are satisfied with the quality of our graduates who typically, after joining the SFS program, significantly improve their GPAs.
  4. The program enabled faculty members to keep abreast of advances in cybersecurity by participating in conferences, workshops, or regional competitions and by disseminating broadly the results of their research and scholarly activities as peer-reviewed papers. This in turn led to the development of more cybersecurity security topics in computer science courses at FSU, benefiting SFS and non-SFS students alike. 

 

 

 


 

 


Last Modified: 01/30/2024
Modified by: Mike V Burmester
por.por_txt_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report

The Department ofComputer Science (CS) at Florida State University (FSU), Tallahassee, has developed a robust infrastructure for cybersecurity education that targets analytical, computational and problem solving skills, to enable CyberCorps (SFS) scholarsto play a leading role in analyzing and better understanding the cybersecurity threat model and to develop protection policies/mechanisms. This includes the establishment of practical-oriented (Hands-on and Challenge-Response) cybersecurity component of the MS degree in Computer Science (Cybersecurity Major). This educational program has contributed to the designation of FSU as a National Center of Academic Excellence inCyber Defense (CAE-CD) and a National Center of Academic Excellence in Research (CAE-R).
Through the CyberCorpsprogram, we recruited some of the most qualified and strongly motivated students from theCollege of Arts and Sciences (including the CS and Mathematics Departments), the College of Criminology & Criminal Justice, the FAMU-FSU College ofEngineering, as well as other schools in Florida. Our educational program offers scholarsa range of courses incybersecurity andcyberdefense both at the undergraduate and graduate levels, while providing an environment that encourages learning and research incybersecurity.
We succesfully recruited six cohorts with an average of eight students per year for 2017-2022, with another three recruited in Spring 2023 (who will continue being funded by the Renewal Award). In total 51 scholars were supported by this award. The program attracted a significant number of female students and underrepresented minorities. All our scholars graduated within three years of receiving the scholarship. We are satisfied with the quality of our graduates who typically, after joining the SFS program, significantly improve their GPAs.
The program enabled faculty members to keep abreast of advances in cybersecurity by participating inconferences, workshops, or regional competitions and by disseminating broadly the results of their research and scholarly activities as peer-reviewed papers. This in turn led to the development ofmore cybersecurity security topics in computer science courses at FSU, benefiting SFS and non-SFS students alike.
